    • Arhitecture and other concepts that one should know

    OOP - Object Orianted Programming

    Building block of any web/desktop/mobile app. Today, building an app in any other way is almost unthinkable. If you write code and you are not doing it with objects, 95% of the time, I would say you are doing it wrong.

    MVC - Model View Controller : Programming concept in which the code is split into three sections.

  • The View and Controller (UI sections) View - part of code that handles rendering the output for the user.
    Controller- part of code that handles incoming requests
  • Model - The buissnes logic. Part of the code in "charge" of all the logic that has to be implemented.

    SOLID principles:

  • Single responsibility principle
  • Open/closed principle
  • Liskov substitution principle
  • Interface segregation principle
  • Dependency inversion principle

    • STUPID code:

    No, this is not meant to be an insult. Its just the way it's written. Watch this: Anthony Ferrara - Don't be STUPID, Grasp SOLID

    • Helpfull tip

    Take it from me, don't think about optimization until it works. Make it work, then make it better, you can't do both at the same time.

    Class AppInDev (){
    protected $name = 'Code block';
    protected $purpose = 'feature';
    protected $works = true;
        
    public function shouldRefactor () {
        if($works == true)
        {
            echo "Sure, go ahead";
        }
        else
        {
            echo "Make it work first";
        }
    }
}

    Helpfull tip no.3

    One Task at a time - don't work on ten features all at once. You will get lost no matter how much experience you have. I learned this first hand when I tried to make 3 projects all at once.

    There is nothing worse then jumping from one thing to another without finishing the task at hand first. You don't want to find yourself looking at your code and not knowing what was happening in it. And this will happen, it's simply the way it is. You will jump to another project and work on in for a week and when the time comes to return to the first one, well, it will take some time to figure out what was happening.

    The sad part is, it's your code.

    Helpfull tip no.2

    Use testing! End of statemant.

    Test driven development might be one of the most important things I learned. Is it easier to test by clicking every feature in the browser or by running a simple phpunit command in the terminal? It might seem that writting test slows you down, but in the long run you will see for yourself that it does the opposite.

    Imagine adding a reply option to a post. Sure, easy to test, click in textarea and post. But what about editing, deleting, voting? Imagine chaning one thing on the reply class, or even the post class, or any class anywhere on the page. You never know when one thing will break another. Do you then spend an hour clicking through every option on the page? Or do you just run a command in the terminal and see the app test itself out?
